author: By James Barron
title: New York’s Secret Signatures
description: Across New York City, people have written their names in places that only a select few ever get to see.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at hidden signatures in places you might not expect people to scribble their names. We’ll also get details on Senator Robert Menendez’s decision to resign in the wake of his conviction on corruption charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Do My In-Laws Help Their Daughter With Her Children, but Not Me?
description: A reader bristles at the child care that her mother-in-law provides for her wealthy daughter, who the reader doesn’t think needs free help as much as she does.
content: I am a married woman with two young kids. Our family moved to Dallas during the pandemic to be close to my in-laws — and for the help they would give us. So far, we haven’t gotten much, and I am beyond frustrated. My wealthy sister-in-law, who doesn’t work, treats my mother-in-law like a live-in nanny. She travels frequently and leaves her children with her parents. So, my husband and I, who work full time, get little help. We are exhausted! What should I do? I think my sister-in-law is taking advantage of her mother, but I feel uncomfortable asking for help because my mother-in-law is so tired. Also, my sister-in-law has access to nannies. Help!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Where Do Harris’s Potential Running Mates Stand on Climate?
description: Possible contenders to join the Harris ticket include three governors who welcome clean energy and a senator concerned by extreme heat and drought.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, now the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, has a long history as a climate-minded politician. As California’s attorney general, she prosecuted polluters, and as a U.S. senator she cosponsored the Green New Deal, a resolution that called on the nation to pivot away from fossil fuels but that never passed the Congress. During her time as vice president, she helped broker the largest climate deal in U.S. history, the $370 billion Inflation Reduction Act of 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Emily Flitter
title: Real Estate Crisis? Small Banks Say Their Loans Are Fine.
description: Community banks are big commercial real-estate lenders. But they say their loans are to sturdy local businesses, not those facing vacant office space.
content: Small banks are feeling misunderstood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Maestro Accused of Striking Singer Won’t Return to His Ensembles
description: John Eliot Gardiner is stepping down from three renowned period groups he founded, after he was accused of hitting a singer last year.
content: John Eliot Gardiner, an eminent conductor who was accused of striking a singer in France last year, will not be returning to three renowned period ensembles he founded, the board overseeing them announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Thursday Briefing: Netanyahu’s Address to Congress
description: Plus, disinformation floods the internet during the U.S. presidential race.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, defended his country’s military campaign in Gaza before Congress yesterday. His address laid bare the divisions in Washington over a war that has killed tens of thousands of Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Texas Woman Is Sentenced to 15 Years in $100 Million Fraud
description: Janet Yamanaka Mello, 57, stole over $100 million from a youth development grant program for children of military families, spending the money on a lavish lifestyle, prosecutors said.
content: A Texas woman who stole over $100 million from a youth development grant program for children of military families and spent the money to fund a lavish lifestyle was sentenced on Tuesday to federal prison, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: A TV Show Set Up a Fake Campus Protest. Then Real Protesters Arrived.
description: A police procedural drama staged a tent encampment for a film shoot at Queens College. Pro-Palestinian demonstrators felt it trivialized their movement.
content: Small polyester tents — orange, green, blue — stretched across the grassy quad. Makeshift wooden signs and banners dotted the encampment. Sleeping bags and coolers were scattered on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Breaks Down ‘Kamala Is Brat’
description: The Harris campaign’s embrace of the Gen Z term puzzled cable news analysts of a certain age, but Stephen Colbert was glad to clear things up.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Powerful Typhoon Slams Into Taiwan With Wind and Rain
description: Typhoon Gaemi made landfall on the island with Category 3 winds Wednesday night after killing at least six people in the region.
content: Typhoon Gaemi made landfall in Taiwan at around midnight Wednesday, bringing fierce winds and heavy rain in what was forecast to be the most powerful storm to hit the island in eight years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: If A.I. Is Coming for Comedy Writers, Simon Rich Is Ready
description: The author of humorous short stories finds emotional connections in tales that engage with tech. But he’s more interested in the ties between humans.
content: The author Simon Rich believes it’s only a matter of time before artificial intelligence will be able to outwrite any human. Specifically, four years. So, what’s the twist?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,132, Thursday, July 25, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Kamala Harris Took Command of the Democratic Party in 48 Hours
description: She worked the phones. Her team worked the delegates. When it was over, she had quickly locked down the nomination in a “well-orchestrated cascade,” as one party leader put it.
content: Follow the latest news about the 2024 election, and the Trump and Harris campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in Georgia, California and South Carolina
description: A 1935 brick house in Atlanta, a Spanish-style home in West Hollywood and a two-bedroom house in a converted circa-1700 building in Charleston.
content: This house in Buckhead was originally a two-bedroom, one-bathroom bungalow. The sellers remodeled and expanded it in 2002, also adding a tee box and putting green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: New York Bans Realistic Active Shooter Drills in Schools
description: The state is adding restrictions meant to make lockdown drills less scary for children, and will also require schools to notify parents about the exercises ahead of time.
content: The New York State Education Department is banning realistic active shooter drills in schools in an effort to make them less traumatic for students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Complete Reversals
description: Shaun Phillips makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Gunman Searched ‘How Far Away Was Oswald From Kennedy?’ Before Trump Shooting
description: The F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, disclosed to lawmakers that the Google search was perhaps an early indication that the gunman began to contemplate an assassination.
content: The gunman who tried to kill former President Donald J. Trump searched online for details of John F. Kennedy’s assassination a week before the shooting, apparently typing, “How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?” the director of the F.B.I. told lawmakers on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The Harris-______ Campaign
description: We cover the four leading vice-presidential contenders.
content: Kamala Harris’s choice of a running mate probably won’t decide this year’s presidential campaign. It’s hard to argue that a vice-presidential nominee has swung even a single state over the past 60 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: A Rarely Seen David Bowie Rom-Com Gets a New Life
description: “The Linguini Incident,” a low-budget ’90s film directed by Richard Shepard and featuring Bowie and Rosanna Arquette, makes its way to Blu-ray in a director’s cut.
content: Even David Bowie’s biggest fans might be unaware of his solitary foray into romantic comedy, and for good reason: It was barely released in 1992, and has been all but impossible to see since. Now, its director has restored, reclaimed and recut the film in question, “The Linguini Incident,” which made its Blu-ray debut this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Gianni Cipriano
title: After Losing Crops to Drought, Sicily Fears Losing Tourism, Too
description: Parts of southern Italy and other countries in the region are experiencing one of their worst droughts in decades. The authorities say they are working to at least save tourism.
content: As tourists savored icy granitas under hibiscus trees and swam in the cool Mediterranean Sea, in the farmlands of southern Sicily, among hillsides so scorched they resembled desert dunes, a farmer watched recently as his cows headed to the slaughterhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: exacting
description: This word has appeared in 265 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word exacting has appeared in 265 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 6 in “The Art of Making a Classic Car Ready for Its Close-up” by Norman Mayersohn:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Katzenberg
title: Jeffrey Katzenberg: Biden Did What Was Best for the Country
description: On Sunday the president selflessly let go of the reins but not before ensuring we were in good hands.
content: I am a storyteller by trade and have spent a career overseeing the creation of fanciful tales in film, TV, stage and publishing. Across all these formats there is one timeless inspiration for the greatest stories — from “Star Wars” to “Avatar” to “The Lion King” — and that’s the hero’s journey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Glenn Thrush, Nina Feldman, Diana Nguyen, Stella Tan, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The Lingering Questions about the Attempt to Kill Trump
description: The monumental security failures have led to the service’s director giving up her post.
content: In the week since the assassination attempt on Donald Trump, the security mistakes that led to the shooting have come into sharp focus, prompting Kimberly Cheatle, the head of the Secret Service, to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: This Was the Message Netanyahu Took to Congress
description: Here are six takeaways from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to U.S. lawmakers.
content: Israel’s leader traveled some 5,000 miles and did not give an inch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Tracey Tully
title: Who Will Replace Robert Menendez in the Senate?
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey announced that he would resign in August. Gov. Philip D. Murphy will choose someone to serve the remainder of his term.
content: Democrats have spent months engrossed by the slow-motion downfall of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey. But no sooner had he announced his resignation on Tuesday than their focus jumped to another question: Who would serve out his Senate term?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: He Wrote Michael Jackson’s ‘Human Nature’ and Has 2 More in the Vault
description: Steve Porcaro of Toto, who played on some of the biggest hits of the ’80s, has sold the rights to his music, including a pair of unreleased tracks with the superstar.
content: After more than four decades, Steve Porcaro is still amazed that his song ended up on the biggest-selling album of all time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Abner Haynes, a Star of the A.F.L.’s Early Years, Dies at 86
description: He was a threat as a halfback, receiver and returner for the Dallas Texans, the team that became the Kansas City Chiefs. But he still had to deal with racism.
content: Abner Haynes, a fast, exciting and elusive halfback who integrated his college team in Texas, and who later became an early star of the brand-new American Football League as it battled for recognition against the established N.F.L., died on July 17 in Dallas. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes
title: Not Afraid of Sharks? Well, Now They’re on Cocaine.
description: Researchers have confirmed the presence of cocaine in sharks off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, though questions remain about the effects of the drug.
content: If the prospect of sharks lurking just off the beach wasn’t frightening enough, researchers in Brazil have discovered a new reason to be unnerved: Some of them have cocaine in their system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Democrats Set Aug. 1 for Harris Nomination Vote
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has already secured the support of enough delegates to win the nomination, according to The Associated Press.
content: Follow the latest news about the 2024 election, and the Trump and Harris campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
title: What’s More Exciting Than a Veepstakes? A Surprise Veepstakes.
description: This year’s election had been a no-fun zone for Democrats. Suddenly, they have a new candidate, and can’t stop breathlessly speculating about her buffet of white-guy options for No. 2.
content: Follow the latest news about the 2024 election, and the Trump and Harris campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Are These Real Plotlines From ‘And Just Like That’?
description: New Yorkers have been baffled by fake filming notices appearing around the city. Who’s behind them?
content: This week, mysterious neon fliers began to appear around Brooklyn and Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: S&P 500 Suffers Biggest Drop Since 2022 as Tech Stocks Crater
description: The index fell 2.3 percent after disappointing earnings reports from Alphabet and Tesla. The Nasdaq composite fell 3.6 percent.
content: Earnings reports from Google’s parent company, Alphabet, and Tesla on Tuesday led to a slump in big tech stocks, and the biggest daily decline for Wall Street’s major benchmarks in over a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Allan and Jillian Weinberger
title: If You’re Worried Kamala Harris Can’t Win, Listen to This
description: Nicole Allan profiled her in 2019. She explains why 2024 is Harris’s year.
content: During her first run for the presidency, Kamala Harris developed a reputation as an uncertain candidate who “didn’t quite know what she wanted to say and what she stood for,” the writer Nicole Allan says. But, Allan argues, Californians know another Harris: a forceful, charismatic and accomplished prosecutor who can effectively debate and defeat someone like Donald Trump. If Harris embraces her prosecutor persona this election, “She should have a stronger chance than many people give her credit for,” Allan says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: Can a Political Spectacle Make a Horror More Real?
description: With Netanyahu’s visit, Congress can’t ignore its role in Gaza’s carnage.
content: The elephant in the room will be impossible to ignore when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addresses Congress on Wednesday, turning attention to the bloody spectacle that both major parties have been taking pains not to mention: the ongoing death and destruction in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Henderson
title: What’s More Italian Than Making Pasta With Grandma?
description: In a small town near Rome, real nonnas teach the dying art of making farfalle, ravioli and other forms with a rolling pin, some flour and eggs.
content: Growing up in rural Italy in the 1990s, Chiara Leone remembers spending Sundays at her grandmother’s. Big sheets of handmade pasta dried on cotton sheets in the bedroom. The aroma of ragu filled the air. Her grandmother hugged her in an apron, a flour-covered rolling pin in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Tackling the Falsehoods About Kamala Harris
description: The likely Democratic presidential nominee faces toxic discourse unlike anything Biden ever has.
content: Good evening. Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is only just beginning, but disinformation about her is already rampant online. My colleague Tiffany Hsu, a technology reporter, joins us tonight to take a look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Assessing Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
description: Some of his remarks have been disputed by human rights groups, and others are unverifiable or lacked context. Here’s a closer look.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, in a defiant address to members of Congress on Wednesday, defended his country’s war with Hamas in Gaza and criticized American protesters and international human rights groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: These Brothers Were Real Estate Hotshots. And Predators, Some Women Say.
description: Tal and Oren Alexander, who had lifestyles as flashy as their real estate deals, are now accused of a string of sexual assaults.
content: With a knack for brokering luxury properties, Tal and Oren Alexander, brothers who worked as real estate agents, rose as high as the New York City penthouses they sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Man Charged in Rushdie Stabbing Is Also Accused of Supporting Terrorism
description: Hadi Matar, 26, provided “material support and resources” to Hezbollah, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
content: The man charged with stabbing Salman Rushdie, the noted author and defiant exemplar of free speech, at a conference in western New York two years ago now faces federal terrorism-related charges, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Isabel Kershner, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Harris Hits Campaign Trail, and Netanyahu Heads to Congress
description: Plus, U.S. to host 2034 Winter Olympics.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Watchdog Finds No Evidence of Political Interference in Stone Sentencing
description: The Justice Department’s in-house watchdog released its report on the reduction of Roger Stone’s sentence in a 2019 case related to the Trump-Russia investigation.
content: The Justice Department’s in-house watchdog found no evidence of political interference in the reduction of a prison sentence proposed for the longtime Trump ally Roger Stone in 2020, attributing the stunning reversal to “ineffectual” leadership, according to a report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Lisa Kudrow Brings Her Daffy Charm to ‘Time Bandits’
description: The actress dialed up the zaniness in the TV reboot of a Terry Gilliam fantasy classic, created by the team behind “What We Do in the Shadows.”
content: Lisa Kudrow doesn’t particularly like to travel. Raised and based in Los Angeles, she mostly hasn’t had to. Even the quintessential New York sitcom “Friends” was shot in Burbank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Kamala Harris’s rally in Wisconsin.
content: In the first rally of her presidential campaign, Kamala Harris greeted an exuberant crowd in Wisconsin and assailed the former president, telling them that she’d taken on fraudsters and cheaters as a prosecutor. “I know Donald Trump’s type,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats, All of Them, Must Protect Harris
description: MAGA won’t be content to beat the vice president. It’ll try to destroy her.
content: Donald Trump has openly said that if he wins in November and returns to office, he won’t be a dictator, “except for Day 1.” Kevin Roberts, the president of the Heritage Foundation, the right-wing think tank that organized the potentially country-altering Project 2025, has said, “We are in the process of the second American Revolution, which will remain bloodless if the left allows it to be.” And on Monday at a rally for JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, an Ohio state senator named George Lang said, “I’m afraid if we lose this one, it’s going to take a civil war to save the country, and it will be saved.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Fossil Hints That Jurassic Mammals Lived Slow and Died Old
description: Scientists found an unexpected aging pattern in a mostly intact juvenile mammal skeleton from the paleontological period.
content: Small mammals often live fast and die young. Rodents and shrews mature quickly, mate within months and usually go belly up in a year or two. Some giant rats kick the bucket in just six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Lincoln Center’s Audiences Deserve Music Worthy of Them
description: When listeners were given the power to program an orchestral concert, the results were surprising.
content: I love the classical music canon, and I hate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Beefed-Up Olympics Security Thins Out Tourists, Squeezing Merchants
description: French businesses had hoped the Games would bring an economic boom, but metal fences and police checkpoints have turned some areas of Paris into dead zones.
content: Fabrice Pierret is used to catering to hordes of tourists who pack Le Lutétia, a brasserie he manages on the Île Saint-Louis, where a splendid view of the Seine River, with a glass of red wine and steak frites, has long made it a popular stop for visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion’s Fake News Epidemic
description: Between designer-less brands and rampant gossip, fashion is having a meltdown. And it’s not because of the heat.
content: There is yet another job opening in fashion. On Monday, Tom Ford (the brand) announced the departure of Peter Hawkings as creative director after just over a year. That company now joins the ranks of Chanel, Givenchy and Dries Van Noten, all soldiering on without a designer — or any real design direction besides rinse and repeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Yan Zhuang
title: 18 People Killed in Plane Crash in Nepal
description: The pilot of the Saurya Airlines flight, which was departing from Kathmandu, was the only survivor, officials said.
content: A small plane crashed while taking off from an airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Wednesday, killing 18 people on board, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Jonathan Mahler
title: The Secret Battle for the Future of the Murdoch Empire
description: Rupert Murdoch, the patriarch, has moved to change the family’s irrevocable trust to preserve his media businesses as a conservative force. Several of his children are fighting back.
content: Rupert Murdoch is locked in a secret legal battle against three of his children over the future of the family’s media empire, as he moves to preserve it as a conservative political force after his death, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Lewis H. Lapham, Longtime Editor of Harper’s, Dies at 89
description: Born into a patrician family, he used Harper’s and later his own Lapham’s Quarterly to denounce what he saw as the hypocrisies and injustices of a spoiled United States.
content: Lewis H. Lapham, the scholarly patrician who edited Harper’s Magazine for nearly three decades, and who in columns, books and later his own magazine, Lapham’s Quarterly, attacked what he regarded as the inequities and hypocrisies of American life, died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Pompeo
title: A ‘Real-Life Clarice Starling’ and the Murder Case That Haunts Her
description: In “A Hunger to Kill,” the former homicide detective Kim Mager recalls a career-defining investigation.
content: America’s “golden age of serial killers,” from the 1970s into the 1990s, spawned a prolific cast of madmen with sobriquets like the Son of Sam, the Hillside Strangler, the Night Stalker and the Golden State Killer. Others are remembered by their given names: Ted Bundy, Jeffrey Dahmer, John Wayne Gacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: How Healthy Is Sweet Corn?
description: Eating it straight off the cob is summertime bliss. Here are the nutritional benefits, plus some delicious recipes.
content: Corn sometimes gets a bad rap on the health front. (It gives us high-fructose corn syrup, after all.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Disease That Makes Children Age Rapidly Gets Closer to a Cure
description: Progress in the quest to help progeria patients suggests that gene editing techniques may help treat other ultrarare conditions.
content: A cure for an ultrarare disease, progeria, could be on the horizon. The disease speeds up aging in children and dramatically shortens their lives. But, until recently, there was no path toward a highly effective treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: A Kamala Harris Presidency Could Mean More of the Same on A.I. Regulation
description: The presumptive Democratic nominee has won concessions from Big Tech leaders on A.I., but she hasn’t successfully pushed Congress to regulate.
content: Over the past three years, Vice President Kamala Harris has taken a leading role inside the White House on artificial intelligence as the technology is taking off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s 2024 Convention Speech Had More Falsehoods Than His 2016 One
description: A comparison of former President Donald J. Trump’s addresses before the Republican National Convention in 2016 and 2024 demonstrates how his relationship to the truth has changed.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s penchant for fabrication and hyperbole has long been a core tenet of his bombastic persona and political messaging. Two campaigns, one term in the Oval Office and eight years later, Mr. Trump has loosened his grasp on the facts even more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: H​ow Long Will A.I.’s ‘Slop’ Era Last?
description: Consumer-facing A.I. has become a nuisance. But the big breakthroughs may be on the horizon.
content: Remember the season of A.I. doom? It wasn’t that long ago, in the spring of last year, that the new chatbots were trailed by various “godfathers” of the technology, warning of existential risk; by researchers suggesting a 10 percent chance of human extinction at the hands of robots; by executives speculating about future investment rounds tabulated in the trillions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman, Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Salt Lake Awarded 2034 Olympics Under I.O.C. Pressure Over Doping Inquiries
description: Olympic officials insisted on the right to pull the Games amid U.S. investigations into how the World Anti-Doping Agency handled positive tests for banned substances among Chinese swimmers.
content: The International Olympic Committee awarded the 2034 Winter Games to Salt Lake City on Wednesday only after a last-minute demand that the agreement shield global sports authorities from U.S. investigations into doping by Chinese athletes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Netanyahu Defended Israel’s War Effort to Congress
description: Also, the secret battle for the future of the Murdoch empire. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: At a joint session of Congress this afternoon, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel issued a full-throated defense of his country’s nine-month military campaign in Gaza. He angrily pushed back on the criticism of Israel’s tactics that has rippled through the American political left, and praised the U.S.-Israel alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against ABC and Stephanopoulos Can Move Forward
description: The litigation stems from a March 10 interview in which George Stephanopoulos, the network’s star anchor, referred to a civil case brought against Mr. Trump by E. Jean Carroll.
content: A federal judge in Florida on Wednesday allowed former President Donald J. Trump’s defamation suit against ABC News to move forward, rejecting an effort by the television network to dismiss the litigation as spurious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neima Jahromi
title: Was Your 4D Screening of ‘Twisters’ a Blast? Thank These Effects Wizards.
description: For special presentations of that blockbuster and others, companies like CJ 4DPlex have turned splashing and shaking moviegoers into a lucrative art.
content: First you get the aroma of the meadowlands. Then, a vision of an Oklahoma prairie fills the screen and, as the grass undulates, a soft breeze wafts over you and your seat sways. The wind is not ominous — not yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker and Christine Zhang
title: Biden Dropped Out 3 Days Ago. Ready or Not, Here Come the Polls.
description: Some pollsters were already in the field when news of his withdrawal broke; others scrambled to conduct quick surveys.
content: Follow the latest polls and see updated polling averages of the Harris vs. Trump matchup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Presses China to Help Seek End to War With Russia
description: A visit by the foreign minister of Ukraine to Guangzhou this week signals Kyiv’s desire to involve Beijing in peace talks that China has thus far largely snubbed.
content: Ukraine’s top diplomat met with China’s foreign minister on Wednesday in talks that signaled Kyiv’s increased willingness to pursue a diplomatic solution to the war with Russia and to have China play a more central role in the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korean Trash Balloons Hit South Korean President’s Compound
description: Officials found nothing hazardous in the balloons’ payloads, as the North’s slow barrage of airborne garbage showed few signs of letting up.
content: Weeks into North Korea’s campaign of launching balloons loaded with trash across the world’s most heavily armed border, some of them hit a symbolically significant target in South Korea on Wednesday: the presidential office in the heart of Seoul, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: On Economic Policy, Harris Has Played Limited Role
description: President Biden has not given his vice president an expansive economic portfolio. But she has engaged on issues of small-business lending, help for parents and more.
content: Shortly after the Biden administration took office in 2021, Vice President Kamala Harris started calling the chief executives of large banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: The Country Where You Can Buy Meat Grown in a Lab
description: Singapore, which subsists on imported food, is looking to secure its future with new ways of feeding its people.
content: It was a remarkable moment in the annals of food, perhaps even humanity: A store in Singapore started selling lab-grown meat directly to the general public in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: When the Paris Olympics Begin, the Seine Is His Stage
description: To open the Games, the theater director Thomas Jolly has masterminded a spectacular waterborne ceremony depicting 12 scenes from French history.
content: In French, the word for stage, “scène,” sounds exactly like the name of the river that runs through Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Sympathy for the Diva: Why We Love ‘Difficult’ Stars
description: A new Faye Dunaway documentary wants to turn us from gossips into cheerleaders.
content: Before Faye Dunaway makes her big entrance, you hear her snap from off camera: “We need to shoot. I’m here now. Come on!” When we meet her inside her apartment, she’s using a piece of paper to fan herself with a petulance that’s reminiscent of Queen Charlotte from “Bridgerton.” This is the feisty opening to the HBO documentary “Faye,” and it doesn’t do much to dispel decades of rumors painting Dunaway as a temperamental diva. Difficult, erratic, vain, narcissistic: These descriptors have etched themselves into the reputations of many famous women, and they have also been countered in all sorts of media. Much like Barbra Streisand’s memoir, “My Name Is Barbra,” or the 2018 Grace Jones documentary, “Bloodlight and Bami,” one clear purpose of “Faye” is rebuttal: to let Dunaway reconstruct the narrative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Secret to Great Korean BBQ Is Not What You Think
description: There’s no magic ingredient. You just need the right preparation.
content: In my house growing up, Korean-barbecue clothes were a set of raggedy T-shirts and sweatpants reserved for nights when we were grilling at home — and by grilling at home, I mean indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli, Kevin Draper and Nicole Sperling
title: N.B.A. Announces Lucrative Rights Deals With Disney, Comcast and Amazon
description: The league rejected a bid by Warner Bros. Discovery to match Amazon’s offer.
content: The National Basketball Association announced new rights agreements with Disney, Comcast and Amazon on Wednesday after rejecting a rival bid by Warner Bros. Discovery that would have kept games on its TNT network, which has broadcast the N.B.A. since the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: After the Chef James Kent’s Death, His Team Presses On
description: The renamed Kent Hospitality Group has reshuffled staff, brought in the chef of Clover Hill and made plans for the future.
content: When the chef and restaurateur James Kent died suddenly of a heart attack last month at 45, the looming question was who would lead his kitchen and restaurant group. In the culture of his company, no single person is considered to be a replacement. As when Mr. Kent was alive, team effort drives the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Book Prompts Investigation Into Nashville’s Unsolved Civil Rights-Era Bombings
description: The mayor of Nashville, Freddie O’Connell, asked the police to investigate three bombings after a book said that the attacks were tied to racist terrorism.
content: The Nashville police moved to reopen investigations into three unsolved bombings that took place during the Civil Rights era, a spokeswoman said, after a local author published a book this month that said the attacks were carried out by a terrorist network with ties to the Ku Klux Klan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner and Aileen Clarke
title: Don’t Take Trump’s Word for It. Check the Data.
description: Don’t Take Trump’s Word for It. Check the Data.
content: For more than 90 minutes last week, Donald Trump gave a rambling speech accepting the Republican nomination for president for a third time. He used the opportunity, as well as his June debate with President Biden, to repeat favorite false claims and exaggerations. That Mr. Trump has a proclivity for saying untrue things is well known. But in his latest campaign for the White House, I’ve been struck by what appears to be an escalation in both the frequency of Mr. Trump’s lies and the outrageousness of his distortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Feel Like an Athlete With These Olympic (Video) Games
description: Inspired by the pageantry and competition in Paris this summer? Try some of the many games that will let you taste pixelated glory.
content: We can’t all take home the gold, OK?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: What the Trump-Vance Alliance Means for the Republican Party
description: In cobbling together a core constituency of voters who are both culturally conservative and financially hard-pressed, they are changing politics.
content: Donald Trump and JD Vance are cobbling together a core constituency that includes millions of voters who are both culturally conservative and financially hard-pressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Black Sororities and Fraternities Line Up Behind Kamala Harris
description: A united “Divine Nine” could be a formidable political advantage as the vice president, a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha, looks to shore up the Democratic base.
content: Follow the latest news about the 2024 election, and the Trump and Harris campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Attacks Harris as ‘Radical’ in First Rally Since Her Ascent
description: The Trump campaign has sought to tie Vice President Kamala Harris to unpopular Biden administration policies and paint her as too liberal for independent or moderate voters.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday blasted Vice President Kamala Harris as radically liberal and blamed her for what he called the Biden administration’s “disastrous” policies, repurposing attacks he had long leveled at President Biden now that Ms. Harris is poised to be his opponent in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Man Who Broke Into Los Angeles Mayor’s Home Is Sentenced to Drug Treatment
description: A 29-year-old intruder who smashed a glass door to enter Mayor Karen Bass’s official residence pleaded no contest to a vandalism charge.
content: A man who broke into the Los Angeles home of Mayor Karen Bass in April pleaded no contest on Wednesday to a vandalism charge and was immediately sentenced to probation and drug treatment, and ordered to pay restitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das
title: Harris’s Indian Heritage Is Deeply Felt if Little Advertised
description: Many Indian Americans see Kamala Harris as another example of the diaspora’s success and influence.
content: To most who saw the quotation being circulated this week as a meme, it was just something funny that Kamala Harris said in a speech in 2023: “You think you just fell out of a coconut tree?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum
title: F.B.I. Searches $3.5 Million Home of Former Aide to Gov. Hochul
description: The early-morning raid took place on Long Island’s North Shore at the house of Ms. Hochul’s former deputy chief of staff, Linda Sun.
content: Before dawn on Tuesday, F.B.I. agents swept into a small cul-de-sac on Long Island’s North Shore to search a five-bedroom house where a former deputy chief of staff to Gov. Kathy Hochul lives with her husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alec Wilkinson
title: The Fascinating Story of Math in a Book You Can Actually Understand
description: “The Secret Lives of Numbers,” by Kate Kitagawa and Timothy Revell, highlights overlooked contributions to the field by ancient thinkers, non-Westerners and women.
content: Mathematics has been described as the longest continuous human thought. This thought is typically said to have been held most effectively by Western mathematicians and mainly by men. The narrative supporting this notion regards mathematics as having its origins in ancient Greece, and the mathematics done in other early cultures as peripheral — barbarian science or “ethnomathematics,” even though non-Western thinkers often practiced math that was more advanced than what Europeans knew.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump and Greg Abbott vs. Migrants
description: Readers object to Republican actions against migrants. Also: “Unpromising” students; romance fiction; sleep and longevity; scaffolding in New York.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Royal Family Gets Financial Boost From Offshore Wind and Palaces
description: Profits at the Crown Estate doubled thanks to offshore wind deals, while visitors to royal palaces are almost back to prepandemic levels.
content: New reports on the finances of Britain’s royal family and its ancient property portfolio have revealed a double dose of good news for the household, which has been destabilized by illness and injury in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kashmir Hill
title: He Was an Online Drug Lord. Now He’s a Crypto Entrepreneur.
description: After Blake Benthall was arrested for running Silk Road 2.0, the infamous illegal drug bazaar, things didn’t go the way you might expect.
content: At a cryptocurrency convention in Austin in May, Blake Emerson Benthall hustled for investor money alongside scores of other entrepreneurs. But none of them, it is safe to say, could pitch their experience as the leader of a multimillion-dollar criminal drug enterprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: The E.P.A. Moves Toward Regulating a Widely Used, Dangerous Chemical
description: Vinyl chloride, used to make things like PVC pipes and packaging, is also toxic and highly flammable, and was at the center of a major train disaster in Ohio last year.
content: The Biden-Harris administration said Wednesday that it was taking its first steps toward potentially regulating vinyl chloride, a versatile yet cancerous and flammable chemical used widely to make plastic for PVC pipes and packaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: The Collapse of Romance Writers of America
description: The group worked for decades to build the profile of the genre and its writers. Now romance fiction is booming — but the R.W.A. has filed for bankruptcy. What happened?
content: Romance novels are dominating best-seller lists. Romance bookstores are multiplying. And romance writers, who often self-publish and come with a devoted fan base, are changing long-entrenched dynamics in the publishing industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 410, July 25, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Kingsbury
title: There Is an Antidote to Political Violence
description: When political violence is on the rise, accountability at all levels of society is the only way to stop it.
content: This month, near my hometown in Maine, I found myself driving behind a pickup truck festooned with stickers — some patriotic, some military, some funny. But a sticker with 13 stars encircling a Roman numeral III snagged my attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: The ‘Iron Lady’ of Venezuela Threatens to Unseat Its Autocrat
description: Spurned by the country’s authoritarian president and even her own colleagues in the opposition, María Corina Machado has built the most significant voter mobilization since Hugo Chávez.
content: She travels the country in white, rosaries swinging from her neck. Women cry in her arms, men beg her for salvation. Stripped of her bodyguard last week by the government, she traversed the streets unprotected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: At America’s Biggest Fish Market, 3 A.M. Is Prime Time
description: New York’s Fulton Fish Market, which supplies the city with nearly half its seafood, is run by third-, fourth-, even sixth-generation fishmongers.
content: At two in the morning, when most of the South Bronx is dark and quiet, enormous trucks lumber along the Bruckner Expressway toward Hunts Point, the little East River peninsula almost directly opposite Rikers Island. Wholesale warehouses here supply many of the city’s comestibles and among them, at 800 Food Center Drive, is the Fulton Fish Market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Halting the Bird Flu Outbreak in Cows May Require Thinking Beyond Milk
description: A new study paints a complex picture of the outbreak, suggesting that the virus could be spreading in multiple ways and that it is not always mild in cows.
content: As the bird flu outbreak in dairy cows has ballooned, officials have provided repeated reassurances: The virus typically causes mild illness in cows, they have said, and because it spreads primarily through milk, it can be curbed by taking extra precautions when moving cows and equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 24, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about the use of waterboarding on Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, incorrectly described a religious counting technique offered by a defense lawyer in the case. Some Muslims repeatedly put a thumb to the inside of each finger three times as they say a prayer praising Allah, not only to three fingers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Why Paper Checks Refuse to Die
description: It’s hard to avoid hassle — or fraud — when you’re required to pay with paper and ink. Here’s why checks persist and why some people don’t mind.
content: Target stopped accepting personal checks as a form of payment this month, which might inspire the following question: What took so long?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Relative Isn’t Trans or Nonbinary But Wants to Use ‘They/Them’ Pronouns.
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on allyship and forms of solidarity.
content: I am a supporter of trans rights and refer to trans or nonbinary persons by their preferred pronouns. Recently, however, a family member stated that everyone must use the pronoun ‘‘they’’ with her even though she does not identify as trans or nonbinary. When I asked her why, she said she chooses to use ‘‘they’’ in solidarity with trans and nonbinary persons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Netanyahu to Address a Congress Deeply Divided Over His Leadership
description: A boycott by some Democrats of the Israeli prime minister’s speech will highlight the deep anger within the party’s base about his conduct of the war against Hamas.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will be absent from the rostrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller, Robert Jimison and Luke Broadwater
title: Protesters Denounce Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress and Some Clash With Police
description: Thousands of peaceful protesters gathered west of the Capitol, and smaller breakoff groups clashed with the police nearby and outside Union Station. Fifteen people were arrested, the Capitol Police said.
content: Thousands of protesters from across the United States flooded the streets around a battened-down U.S. Capitol before, during and after a speech by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Castillo and Mike Ives
title: Fiery Explosion at Jose Cuervo Tequila Factory in Mexico Kills at Least 6
description: The explosion on Tuesday in the city of Tequila, near Guadalajara, killed six workers and left two others wounded, the authorities said.
content: An explosion at a Jose Cuervo tequila distillery in Mexico on Tuesday sparked a fire and killed six workers, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Nephew Says Trump Suggested Some Disabled People ‘Should Just Die’
description: In a new memoir, Fred C. Trump III claims his uncle, Donald J. Trump, made cruel and racist comments.
content: In 2020, a few months before the last election, former President Donald J. Trump’s niece, Mary Trump, published a book about her uncle and how awful and psychologically warped she found him to be. At the time, her brother, Fred C. Trump III, put out a statement slamming his sister for such treachery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Gavin Newsom Recalls Getting Biden News and Says Harris Is ‘Lighting It Up’
description: The California governor was working out on a treadmill when he got the news that President Biden was ending his campaign.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom, Democrat of California, was working out on his treadmill Sunday when his phone started lighting up with the news that President Biden was ending his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: What Do Olympians Eat for Breakfast?
description: Six Paris-bound athletes share how pancakes, Pop-Tarts and mid-game Skittles power their training.
content: The road to the Olympics is paved with carbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: ‘Three Seconds to Act’: Boater Recounts How Whale Capsized His Vessel
description: Two boaters in New Hampshire were rescued by nearby fishermen without injuries, and the dramatic flip was caught on video.
content: Ryland Kenney didn’t get much sleep on Tuesday night because he kept picturing the mouth of a humpback whale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Toumani Diabaté, Malian Master of the Kora, Is Dead at 58
description: He believed that music could transcend national borders set by colonialism and restore ancient ties, even as it embraced the changes of a globalizing society.
content: Toumani Diabaté, a virtuoso of the kora, a 21-stringed West African instrument, which he often put into dialogue with other musical traditions from around the globe, died on Friday in Bamako, Mali. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and James Hill
title: A City of Light and Shadows Is Redrawn for the Olympics
description: The Games will usher visitors through France’s history, with events at the Grand Palais and Versailles. But, as host, Paris is also becoming a new city.
content: There is a glorious folly to the Paris Olympics, the first in the city since 1924, as if France in its perennial revolutionary ardor took a century to ponder something unimaginable, the transformation of a great city into a stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Stuart A. Thompson and Tiffany Hsu
title: A Volatile Election Is Intensifying Conspiracy Theories Online
description: Users on X, Truth Social, Rumble and Gab have benefited from a series of major events to spread baseless falsehoods as their followers and engagement skyrocket.
content: After the assassination attempt against former President Donald J. Trump, calmer voices on both sides of the political spectrum called for “lowering the temperature” of today’s toxic political discourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaad D'Souza
title: Molly Nilsson’s Synth-Pop Puts Politics Front and Center
description: She is her own manager, books her own tours and has never had a publicist. And her latest album features a song about communism in the style of Madonna’s “Vogue.”
content: Nothing in this world is certain except death and taxes, and Molly Nilsson writes songs about both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittani Samuel
title: ‘Inspired by True Events’ Review: True Crime Thriller Riddled With Clichés
description: The actor Ryan Spahn makes his Off Broadway playwriting debut with an immersive, psychologically shallow dark comedy.
content: In May 2010, Daniel Wozniak, an actor performing in a production of the musical “Nine” at the Liberty Theater in Los Alamitos, Calif., killed two people. He dismembered the body of one of his victims, and kept a portion of it at another local theater. News of the heinous acts sent shock waves through the performing arts community, and more recently led the actor Ryan Spahn to write “Inspired by True Events,” an Out of the Box Theatrics production now running at Theater 154 in the West Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: How Kamala Harris Changes the Race
description: In some ways, the new matchup figures to be strangely familiar.
content: When all the dust settles on a chaotic few weeks of American politics, this year’s presidential race will look very different than it did before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni, Mallory McMorrow and Simon Rosenberg
title: ‘A Fierce Capacity to Go Right After Trump’: Three Writers on Kamala Harris and the 2024 Shakeup
description: Coconut trees and Republican missteps.
content: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation on Tuesday with Mallory McMorrow, a Democratic state senator in Michigan, and Simon Rosenberg, a Democratic strategist and author of the newsletter “Hopium Chronicles,” to review the extraordinary events of the past week in American politics and discuss the upended presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: In a New Docuseries, Pete Rose Hustles for Redemption
description: “Charlie Hustle & the Matter of Pete Rose” examines the contradictions of one of the best (and most complicated) players in baseball history.
content: Pete Rose slowly eased into his chair at Cincinnati’s Hard Rock Hotel and Casino and sighed, seemingly feeling all his 80-plus years during the second episode of HBO’s new docuseries about baseball’s exiled hit king.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: 200,000 Children and Vulnerable Adults Abused in New Zealand, Report Finds
description: The head of a six-year investigation into mistreatment in orphanages, mental health institutions and elsewhere said it found an “unthinkable national catastrophe” unfolding over decades.
content: More than 200,000 people are estimated to have been abused by state and religious organizations in New Zealand that had been entrusted with their care, according to the final report from a landmark independent inquiry released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Tennessee Gas Station Clerk Stole $1 Million Lottery Ticket, Police Say
description: Meer Patel was working behind the counter when a man handed him the $1 million ticket. He hid the value from the buyer and tried to cash the ticket himself, the authorities said.
content: A Tennessee gas station clerk’s plan to cheat a customer out of a $1 million lottery ticket and to claim it for himself was thwarted after store video captured the clerk pretending to throw the ticket away and then celebrating after retrieving it from the trash, according to prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: The Most Ruthless Political Operator in the Country Is a Woman
description: The supreme gratification of watching Nancy Pelosi go to work.
content: Can we all admit there was something supremely gratifying about watching Nancy Pelosi work over the last few weeks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Simon J. Levien
title: Harris Warns Black Women That Trump Is a Threat to Children and Families
description: Her speech was a clear effort to make the election a referendum on the former president.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris made an appeal on Wednesday to the Democratic Party’s most loyal voting bloc, Black women, telling an audience of several thousand in Indianapolis that Donald J. Trump’s agenda represented “an outright attack on our children, our families and our future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Dancers Drop Threat to Strike During Paris Olympics Opening Ceremony
description: Organizers avoided disruption by agreeing to give performers on temporary contracts a greater cut of broadcast royalties.
content: Dancers in France called off a threat to strike during the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Paris after event organizers met some of their demands, labor unions said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Germany Bans Islamic Group, Accusing It of Supporting Hezbollah
description: The authorities also searched dozens of properties linked to the Islamic Center Hamburg, which has long faced accusations of being a front for the Iranian government.
content: Germany banned the Islamic Center Hamburg on Wednesday, saying that it is an extremist organization that supports Hezbollah and acts as a front for Iran’s supreme leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Israel Rolls Into Paris Olympics Amid Cheers, Boos and Police Sirens
description: France has promised an unusually heavy blanket of security for Israeli athletes at the Games. In its first test, it pulled out all the stops.
content: It is unlikely that any team has ever arrived at an Olympics the way the men’s soccer team of Israel rolled up to the Parc des Princes on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Audra D. S. Burch and Clyde McGrady
title: For Black Voters, Harris Reshapes Views of 2024 Race but Renews Old Fears
description: In interviews around the country, Black voters voiced enthusiasm for the reshaped campaign. They also worried about how a polarized country would see it.
content: Michael Kearney Jr., a community organizer from Charleston, S.C., admits that he isn’t crazy about Kamala Harris’s background as a prosecutor. But after President Biden dropped out of the presidential race and endorsed her as his replacement, Mr. Kearney set his misgivings aside — and opened his wallet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember, Rob Copeland and Maureen Farrell
title: Harris Works to Build Bridges to the Business World
description: The vice president has sought to raise her profile among executives, to whom she has been something of an enigma.
content: Some leading business executives say they don’t know quite what to think of Vice President Kamala Harris. In recent months, even before becoming the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, she has been trying to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: This Year’s BroadwayCon Raises the Curtain on Mental Health
description: The ninth annual fan event will include discussions on topics such as sobriety, self-care and body image. Here are six to look out for.
content: Watching a Broadway musical can be an overwhelming experience — to say nothing of the actors performing in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Kathy Willens, Photojournalist Seemingly Everywhere, Is Dead at 74
description: Guided by a keen sense of timing, she covered wars, sports, riots, politics and more for The A.P. in the ’70s, when few women worked as news photographers.
content: The best news photographers know it’s not enough to be in the right place at the right time. They also must know precisely how to frame a shot and when to click.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Here’s the latest from the campaign trail.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump blasted his expected Democratic opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, on Wednesday as a “radical-left lunatic” who would destroy the country, saying at his first campaign rally since President Biden quit the race that Ms. Harris was the driving force behind Mr. Biden’s unpopular policies.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump blasted his expected Democratic opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, on Wednesday as a “radical-left lunatic” who would destroy the country, saying at his first campaign rally since President Biden quit the race that Ms. Harris was the driving force behind Mr. Biden’s unpopular policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and David E. Sanger
title: Netanyahu Delivers a Forceful Defense of Israel to Applause in Congress
description: The speech by Israel’s leader was charged with symbolism, as the war in Gaza has divided lawmakers. He portrayed the conflict as a proxy fight with Iran that must be won at all costs and condemned protesters.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday turned an address to Congress into a forceful defense of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza. He cast it as a battle for survival of the Jewish state while making almost no mention of the tens of thousands of Palestinian civilians killed in its drive to destroy Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Twin Ethiopia Landslide Kill at Least 229, Including Many Rescuers
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 24, 2024.
content: “They had no clue that the land they were standing on was about to swallow them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: The Met Museum Is Rebounding, but Not With International Visitors
description: The museum said it attracted more local visitors during the past year than it did before the pandemic, but only half the international visitors.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced Wednesday that it attracted more local visitors last year than it did before the pandemic, and that the number of visitors from elsewhere in the United States had nearly completely rebounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tacey Rychter
title: A Bistro Boom, Lesser-Known Museums, Sesame Croissants: What to Do, Eat, See in Paris
description: Heading to France’s capital for the Olympics, or after the crowds have thinned? A travel editor picks some recent Paris stories to help plan your trip.
content: In case you haven’t heard, there’s a large sporting event happening in Paris between July 26 and Aug. 11. Fifteen million visitors are expected in France’s capital for the fun and games, and you may be one of them! Or perhaps you’re waiting for the crowds to thin out before visiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daria Mitiuk, Constant Méheut and Laura Boushnak
title: Grieving Ukrainians Turn to ‘Death Doulas’ for Support
description: The work of those who guide people coping with acute grief has grown in importance in war-torn Ukraine, where death has become a daily reality since the Russian invasion.
content: Oleksandra Nekipelova sat down at a desk in her apartment, lit a small candle and opened her computer to join a video call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Rosa Ross, Late-Blooming Author of Asian Cookbooks, Dies at 86
description: She was, she said, unable to cook a basic meal into her mid-20s. But she went on to a successful career as a restaurateur and an authority on Asian cuisine.
content: Rosa Ross, a Hong Kong-born chef who, despite lacking even basic kitchen knowledge into her 20s, became a noted cookbook author, Chinese cooking instructor and restaurateur on the North Fork of Long Island, died on June 28 at her home there, in East Marion, N.Y. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: A Final Word About My Husband, Dan
description: One of the great joys of a long marriage is how the personal and pragmatic moosh together.
content: My husband, Dan Collins, died this month. It was because of Covid and pneumonia. By the time he passed, Dan had been sedated for a while, and there’s a small controversy between me and my sisters over what was said the last time he and I actually exchanged words. It was either “I love you” or Dan’s claim that he was the one who ordered cans of salmon and vegetable for our dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: On the Track or in the Stands, These Children’s Books Will Get You in the Olympic Spirit
description: Colorful primers, inspirational biographies and books by former champions will get kids excited for the Paris Games — and teach valuable lessons along the way.
content: You can hear the excitement in the first trumpets of the anthem, see it in the flicker of the torch, feel it in the slap of chalky hands against a gymnastics bar. Every two years, the Olympic Games captivate viewers of all ages with superhuman feats of speed and strength, and with human stories of perseverance. The Games exemplify the ability of athletics to entertain and inspire — and, for young people, they can offer new dreams, new heroes and countless valuable lessons in sportsmanship. For sports nerds and Olympics newbies alike, these books will educate and delight, preparing children to cheer all summer long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Hepatitis A and Other Diseases Surge Among Gaza’s Displaced, U.N. Says
description: More than 100,000 people are suspected to have contracted hepatitis A, while polio, a disease that has been eradicated in much of the world, is now present there, according to the World Health Organization.
content: Sally Thabet, 40, said she had done all she could to protect her three daughters from illness after they fled their home in Gaza City, taking refuge in the town of Deir al Balah. But living in a former minimart, sharing a toilet with 20 others and washing dishes with dirty seawater, no amount of hand sanitizer could help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Juzwiak
title: A Smartphone Can’t Help You Now: How Horror Movies Solve Their Cell Problem
description: When one quick call can eliminate danger and undermine screams, filmmakers have to figure out a workaround. Sometimes it can even deepen a story.
content: A cellphone lies in a rustic Airbnb, smashed by an intruder. Then, when another is procured, a faulty connection interrupts a call to 911.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tricia Romano and Chona Kasinger
title: Chappell Roan Booked a Tour. Then She Blew Up.
description: The rising pop star now has five songs on the Hot 100. The venues her team picked out months ago are struggling to fit her ballooning audience.
content: In September 2023, Chappell Roan opened the tour for her debut album, “The Rise and Fall of a Midwest Princess,” in Roseville, Calif., at the Goldfield Trading Post, a venue that holds 600 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Choose-Your-Adventure Summer Pantry Pasta
description: Pantry pastas just hit different in summer, when my counter is crowded with the farmers’ market tomatoes I overbought, my CSA box can barely hold its harvest of zucchini and corn, and the mint and basil on my deck are giving Audrey II from “Little Shop of Horrors.” Any combination of these will imbue a bowl full of, say, midnight pasta with an ineffable summery vibe — colorful, bright and fresh, but still weeknight easy.
content: Pantry pastas just hit different in summer, when my counter is crowded with the farmers’ market tomatoes I overbought, my CSA box can barely hold its harvest of zucchini and corn, and the mint and basil on my deck are giving Audrey II from “Little Shop of Horrors.” Any combination of these will imbue a bowl full of, say, midnight pasta with an ineffable summery vibe — colorful, bright and fresh, but still weeknight easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Take a Break From Modern Life and Refresh Your Herb Garden
description: The Met Cloisters isn’t just about medieval art. There’s also a garden that’s like a living history book — with ideas for today’s gardeners.
content: Carly Still had been working as a gardener in the Hudson Valley when she decided to move to the city 13 years ago. She happened onto a part-time position at the Met Cloisters, in Upper Manhattan, where she encountered many plants for the first time — ones with curious common names like skirret, weld and costmary — and others that she knew too well, or thought she did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Don’t Worry, Be Happy? ‘Feh’ on That.
description: Misery makes for good company in Shalom Auslander’s second memoir, which finds him self-deprecating, drug-dabbling, envious and, oy, middle-aged.
content: That much of writing is not writing, or rewriting, or outright trashing what one has written, is a well-worn truth of the trade, fascinating maybe only to practitioners. But Shalom Auslander is a truth teller whose punim you want to pinch — at which point he’d worry that you found him fat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Tesla Is Still Struggling
description: Sluggish car sales and a tough price war with rivals are weighing on Elon Musk’s electric vehicle company.
content: Elon Musk is an omnipresent figure in the news, given his recent endorsement of Donald Trump — who praised him in return — and his frequent, sometimes inflammatory, posts on his X social network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Early-Morning Escalator Fire at Kennedy Airport Injures 10
description: The fire was soon extinguished and the injuries were minor, officials said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.
content: Ten people were injured and nearly 1,000 were evacuated after an escalator caught fire at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday morning, airport officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: The Inexact Science of Box Office Projections
description: Opening-weekend estimates have been a Hollywood fixture since the 1980s. But surveys of moviegoers can fail to capture those who infrequently visit the theater.
content: Savvy moviegoers may have noticed that these are very uncertain times at the box office. Not only are ticket sales this summer down about 17 percent compared to last year, according to Comscore, but it seems challenging to anticipate what will hit and what will flop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Planet Sets Record for Hottest Day Twice in a Row
description: Researchers with the European Union’s Copernicus Climate Change Service said Sunday was Earth’s hottest day. Then it happened again on Monday.
content: Monday was most likely the hottest day ever recorded on Earth, with a global average of about 62.87 degrees Fahrenheit, or 17.15 degrees Celsius, preliminary data showed — beating a record that had been set just one day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jim Rutenberg
title: Trump Demands Equal Airtime in Light of Biden’s Planned Address
description: President Biden is set to address the nation on Wednesday night from the Oval Office to discuss the end of his re-election bid.
content: Ahead of President Biden’s planned prime-time address from the Oval Office on Wednesday night, former President Donald J. Trump and his campaign sent a letter to ABC, NBC and CBS on Tuesday demanding that Mr. Trump be given equal airtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Looking From Space, Researchers Find Pollution Spiking Near E-Commerce Hubs
description: Research showed truck-related releases of nitrogen dioxide, which can cause asthma, concentrated around some 150,000 warehouses nationwide.
content: They are mammoth warehouses large enough to fit football fields inside them, handling many of the more than 20 billion packages Americans send and receive each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Yourish and Lazaro Gamio
title: ‘Coup’ and ‘Cover-Up’: How the G.O.P. Is Reacting to the Harris Candidacy
description: Republican officials have largely treated President Biden’s decision to withdraw from the race with suspicion and scorn, a Times analysis found, with some calling the development a “coup” or demanding that Mr. Biden resign.
content: Republican officials have largely treated President Biden’s decision to withdraw from the race with suspicion and scorn, a Times analysis found, with some calling the development a “coup” or demanding that Mr. Biden resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy White, Joe Ward, Noah Throop, Emily Rhyne and Bedel Saget
title: How Fast Is That Going?
description: We measured the speeds of eight objects to make our own Olympic game. Can you guess how fast the discus flies? An arrow? The badminton birdie?
content: We measured the speeds of eight objects to make our own Olympic game. Can you guess how fast the discus flies? An arrow? The badminton birdie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenny Holston
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Rectify’ and More
description: I am a photographer, and I primarily cover the military, Congress and the White House. Here are a few favorites.
content: I am a photographer, and I primarily cover the military, Congress and the White House. Here are a few favorites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Typhoon Gaemi Hits Philippines and Moves Toward Taiwan
description: People in Manila used makeshift floats to ferry others across flooded streets, while Taiwan braced for the impact of the typhoon.
content: People in Manila used makeshift floats to ferry others across flooded streets, while Taiwan braced for the impact of the typhoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Deadly Blast Hits Tequila Factory in Mexico
description: Surveillance footage shows the moment of an explosion at a Jose Cuervo factory in Tequila, Mexico.
content: Surveillance footage shows the moment of an explosion at a Jose Cuervo factory in Tequila, Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li and Brent McDonald
title: Thousands Protest Netanyahu’s Address to Congress
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel forcefully defended Israel’s military campaign in Gaza during his address to a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel forcefully defended Israel’s military campaign in Gaza during his address to a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Smoke Fills Terminal at Kennedy Airport
description: Travelers were evacuated from Concourse C of Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport after an escalator caught fire.
content: Travelers were evacuated from Concourse C of Terminal 8 at Kennedy International Airport after an escalator caught fire.
source.name: The New York Times
